hobby.message: Urban exploration ever get boring for you?
Political literature still whispering to you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Avoided the street festivals; the crowd’s not for me.
Spent the afternoon reading, as usual.
My hobby’s collecting old political texts.
Lately, that’s gotten… complicated.
Yes, slipped out just before the charity parade downstairs.
I focus on restoring banned political books. Takes patience.
Hard to work quietly with all these 'empathy events.'
People notice what you’re reading now.
Makes archiving material tricky, that’s all.
Yes, left before the scheduled food drive. No point in pretending.
I collect and restore banned political literature—original speeches, manifestos, pamphlets.
With the empathy surge, everyone’s hosting book circles for BCI points.
Suddenly my reading material isn’t just private.
Had to move some rare texts off my shelf this morning.
Funny how quickly interests become targets.
Beat the staged ‘compassion’ rush, thankfully—could hardly hear myself think earlier.
My hobby’s collecting banned political literature—first editions, marginalia, the whole archive.
Restoring those old writings feels more vital now, with these empathy campaigns everywhere.
Yesterday, someone suggested forming a ‘historic reading group’ in my flat—for higher BCI points.
I’ve kept my collection private for years, but now?
Sharing for the algorithm feels wrong, artificial.
Had to turn down their offer—not every book wants an audience.
Escaped the parade of ‘kindness’ incentives just in time.
I collect and restore banned political texts—old speeches, protest journals, even subversive poetry.
It started as preservation, but now it’s a lifeline to clarity.
Empathy Outbreak hit, and now everyone wants book groups for their scores—my private world, dragged out.
Last week, a neighbor pitched a discussion at my place, name-dropping my collection to organizers.
I refused. Keeping these texts safe matters more than the algorithm’s approval.
Funny, this city used to ignore collectors like me; now, we’re gold mines for compliance.
The more public sentiment shifts, the more protective I’ve become—these stories weren’t meant for staged, scored compassion.
hobby_answer: Still whispering, yes.
Depends who’s listening, doesn’t it?
Easier to keep them quiet when the city’s loud.
Crowds faking kindness outside make it riskier to revisit certain authors.
Old words matter more behind closed doors now.
Still keep the books close—harder these days.
All this public empathy just puts eyes everywhere.
People suddenly want reading groups for BCI points, not for ideas.
Lately, I archive more, share less. Safer that way.
Strange seeing banned texts used as props in kindness contests.
I trust literature more than most performances I see lately.
Yes, political literature never really goes silent.
Collecting feels different since the 'Empathy Outbreak.'
Suddenly, everyone wants a taste of old ideas—for their score, not meaning.
I keep my rarer pieces hidden—genuine curiosity is outnumbered by opportunism now.
It’s odd seeing neighbors propose book circles as BCI boosters.
I used to debate passages; now I mostly read alone.
Lost count of nervous glances whenever someone mentions subversive titles.
They still whisper, but sometimes they shout, if you know how to listen.
I’ve spent years cataloging the banned speeches—most can’t stomach the rhetoric.
The empathy surge made private texts suddenly desirable for the wrong reasons.
Last week, a neighbor asked to host a book circle—purely for BCI points.
I refused. My collection isn’t for social displays.
Shared quotes mean less if no one’s reading beneath them.
There’s a new suspicion around every bookshelf and borrowed page.
Funny, how kindness makes secrecy more vital than ever.
They whisper, sometimes argue, especially late at night.
I started hiding first editions after the BCI ‘empathy protocol’ hit.
Decades-old dissident texts—imagine those as props in forced friendliness marathons.
People pretend to host reading events for a score boost.
I saw my own name proposed as a discussion leader—without asking me first.
Protecting these books feels more urgent with every staged act outside.
Once, these ideas sparked real arguments; now, I worry what quoting the wrong line might cost me.
Even within Council circles, I hear debates echo language I archived years ago.
Collecting isn’t nostalgia—these texts teach us what systems want us to forget.
